examTips: Read carefully; materiality and disclosure are common traps.

questions.question: A client is interested in purchasing a life insurance policy but has recently been diagnosed with a chronic condition. The agent is aware of the diagnosis but does not mention it to the insurer, believing it is not severe.
options: A. Policy will likely be issued without issue
B. Agent acted ethically by protecting the client
C. Material misrepresentation has occurred
D. Disclosure is optional if client requests confidentiality
questions.explanation: Materiality is determined by the insurer, not the agent’s perception. Failure to disclose a known condition = misrepresentation.

questions.question: A client asks for advice on a policy. The agent recommends a replacement that resets the suicide clause without disclosing this change.
options: A. Replacement is ethical because client consented
B. Agent violated the duty of disclosure
C. Only relevant if client loses money
D. No issue if agent believes it is in client’s best interest
questions.explanation: Suicide clause reset = material disadvantage. Consent without disclosure = meaningless; agent must disclose.

questions.question: A financial advisor receives a referral fee from a mortgage broker for each insurance policy sold. The advisor does not disclose this arrangement to the client.
options: A. Acceptable because client is aware of all fees
B. Minor ethical issue
C. Conflict of interest that must be disclosed
D. Only problematic if fee exceeds 10%
questions.explanation: Any personal benefit that could influence advice is a conflict of interest and must be disclosed, regardless of size.

questions.question: A policyholder wishes to assign their life insurance to a third party, and the agent proceeds without confirming the third party’s legal capacity.
options: A. Assignment valid because policyholder consented
B. Legal risk because third party may lack capacity
C. Agent has no responsibility
D. Valid as long as insurer signs
questions.explanation: Legal capacity is required to transfer contracts. Failure to confirm capacity exposes agent and insurer to legal risk.

questions.question: An elderly client is pressured by family members to buy a policy quickly. Agent completes the application without assessing client understanding.
options: A. Ethical because client signed
B. Undue influence ignored → unethical
C. Acceptable if family helps with paperwork
D. Only unethical if client complains
questions.explanation: Vulnerable client + pressure = undue influence; agent must protect client and pause the sale.

questions.question: An agent recommends a policy because it provides a larger commission, even though a cheaper alternative is equally suitable.
options: A. Ethical if client benefits marginally
B. Unethical due to undisclosed conflict of interest
C. Acceptable if client signs agreement
D. Only problematic if client loses money
questions.explanation: Undisclosed personal benefit influencing recommendation = ethics breach; disclosure is required.

questions.question: Client provides false information unintentionally. Agent suspects but proceeds anyway.
options: A. Agent is protected because error was unintentional
B. Submission = ethical
C. Material misrepresentation may occur
D. Insurance company must verify all info
questions.explanation: Suspicion obligates the agent to investigate and clarify; unintentional error does not remove misrepresentation risk.

questions.question: A policyholder dies shortly after absolute assignment. The new owner does nothing before death. Who receives the death benefit?
options: A. Former owner
B. Successor policyholder
C. Named beneficiary
D. Policyholder’s estate
questions.explanation: An absolute assignment transfers ownership; if the new owner dies without action, the benefit passes to their estate.

questions.question: Which of the following is a prohibited sales practice?
options: A. Churning
B. Transparent replacement with consent
C. Honest disclosure of commission
D. Product recommendation based on suitability
questions.explanation: Churning (unnecessary replacements for gain) is prohibited; the others are ethical or neutral when done properly.

questions.question: An agent receives a complaint that a client feels coerced into a purchase. What is the first step?
options: A. Deny responsibility
B. Document complaint and report internally
C. Offer commission rebate
D. Proceed as sale already closed
questions.explanation: Documenting and reporting the complaint is the correct first step per regulatory and ethical standards.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about common-law partners and insurance rights is correct?
options: A. Property division applies like in marriage
B. Only spousal support is available
C. Cohabitation agreement can retroactively grant rights
D. Common-law partner has all rights of a spouse
questions.explanation: Common-law status may create spousal support obligations; property division rules differ from marriage in many jurisdictions.

questions.question: A client asks the agent whether a policy is protected from creditors. The agent answers “Yes” without verifying provincial laws.
options: A. Acceptable as a general rule
B. Misrepresentation; advice must be verified
C. Ethical if client trusts the agent
D. Only an issue if creditor sues
questions.explanation: Legal protections vary by province; the agent must verify and not assume protections.

questions.question: Which statement best describes FINTRAC reporting obligations?
options: A. Only required if client appears suspicious to peers
B. Required within 15 days for suspicious transactions
C. Optional if agent believes report may harm client
D. Report must be filed only if client threatens legal action
questions.explanation: FINTRAC rules require timely reporting (within 15 days) for suspicious transactions; good-faith protection applies.

questions.question: An agent fails to explain a living benefit on a policy. Which principle is breached?
options: A. Product suitability
B. Duty of care
C. Conflict of interest
D. Client autonomy
questions.explanation: Failing to explain material features breaches the duty of care owed to the client.

questions.question: Which is an example of undue influence?
options: A. Offering product options
B. High-pressure tactics on vulnerable client
C. Explaining benefits clearly
D. Giving commission disclosure
questions.explanation: High-pressure tactics on a vulnerable client are classic undue influence.

questions.question: A client wants a policy assignment but is a minor. The agent proceeds with parent consent only.
options: A. Assignment valid
B. Invalid due to legal capacity
C. Valid if insurer agrees
D. Valid if minor signs
questions.explanation: Minors generally lack capacity to hold contracts; parental consent alone does not make assignment valid.

questions.question: Which is required for ethical replacement of life insurance?
options: A. Written disclosure of new vs old features
B. Verbal explanation only
C. Agent discretion for client convenience
D. Replacement is always ethical
questions.explanation: Written disclosure with documentation provides a clear record and safeguards the client; verbal alone is insufficient.

questions.question: Which statement about conflicted referrals is true?
options: A. Referrals may be rewarded without disclosure
B. Referral arrangement must be disclosed to client
C. Only prohibited if fee > $1000
D. Discretionary if client trusts agent
questions.explanation: Any financial incentive creating potential influence must be disclosed to the client.

questions.question: When is silence considered misrepresentation?
options: A. Only if client asks
B. When material information is withheld
C. Never, silence is neutral
D. Only if policyholder loses money
questions.explanation: Withholding material information that the client should know constitutes misrepresentation.

questions.question: A client is partially confused but wants to proceed with an application. The agent continues without ensuring understanding.
options: A. Ethical if client pays premiums
B. Unethical due to lack of informed consent
C. Acceptable if family approves
D. Only issue if claim denied
questions.explanation: Proceeding without ensuring informed consent is unethical; agent must confirm understanding before completing the transaction.
